title: BEAUMONT: Seniors have many options for transportation
text:
By RICHARD MONTENEGRO BROWN / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 5, 2015 10:13 a.m. BEAUMONT: Seniors have many options for transportation Print Photo Share Pin It 1 of 2 More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT Pass Transit driver Phyllis Williamson, left, speaks with Martha Roberts, center, and Elaine Tisler during a tour of a dial-a-ride vehicle. RICHARD MONTENEGRO BROWN , STAFF Related article » TRIP TRANSPORTATION  It started in 1993 in the Coachella Valley.
 It provided 1.8 million miles of free trips in Riverside County in 2014.
 It provided 127,000 trips to 1,028 unique users in 2014.
 Since 1993, 1.4 million free trips have been provided.
 To sign up, call 800-510-2020 or go to ilpconnect.org.
Retiree Martha Roberts said she bikes up to 20 miles every morning – a far cry from the senior citizens with limited or no mobility that Beaumont officials were trying to reach last week.
Roberts, as a facilitator of a bereavement group at the Solara senior community where she lives, said she wanted to learn about transportation services for seniors in Beaumont to share with her group.
“I come across a lot of people who don’t drive, who are dependent on others,” she said.
That is precisely who Mayor Brenda Knight was reaching out to Wednesday, Sept. 30, when she brought together transportation officials and seniors for an informational session at the Beaumont Senior Citizens Center on Oak Valley Parkway.
“A lot of the programs that are available are not getting out to the community at large,” Knight said.
Seniors heard presentations from the countywide Riverside Transit Agency and from Pass Transit, which serves Beaumont, Banning, Cherry Valley and Calimesa in the San Gorgonio Pass with fixed bus routes and dial-a-ride services for seniors and the disabled.
Knight, however, drew particular attention to what she believes is a little-known nonprofit program called TRIP transportation of Riverside County.
The program started in 1993 and flies under the radar – on purpose, Executive Director Richard Smith said. TRIP seemingly serves as a last resort for seniors who need transportation. Smith said the program reimburses qualifying seniors for trips and rides provided by private individuals. TRIP advances the senior a check and the senior pays the person who gave him or her a ride.
Last year, Smith said, the program paid for 127,000 free trips for 1,028 unique users in Riverside County.
Leaders with the Beaumont-based Pass Transit also seek to enhance senior services. Attendees Wednesday were urged to fill out a needs survey before leaving.
Claudia Shields of Cherry Valley said she suggested establishing more fixed routes for seniors like herself. She lives north of Wal-Mart in Beaumont. As it stands, the fixed route travels in a east-west circuit; she wants to see a north-south route to cut down a trip that takes 45 minutes.
Beaumont resident Brenda Teeman wants to see the city establish a taxi subsidy service, and is working with other seniors and Knight to explore such a program.
Teeman moved to Beaumont from Walnut, where a similar program is in place that directly pays taxi companies to transport seniors to medical appointments and facilities.
Knight said the intent of Wednesday’s event was to serve the community’s seniors as best as the city can, to return the favor.
“They served all of us their whole lives,” she said. “They are a very significant part of our community.”
